Android is an open-source operating system based on the Linux kernel, primarily designed for touchscreen devices such as smartphones and tablets. It was developed by Google in partnership with several major hardware manufacturers like Samsung, HTC, and LG.

With its official debut in 2008, Android has grown to become one of the most widely used mobile operating systems globally. Android offers a feature-rich platform that provides developers a chance to create various types of apps catering to users' needs across different sectors.

Key features that distinguish Android from other operating systems include:

1. Open Source: One significant advantage of Android over many other platforms (such as iOS) is its open-source nature. This allows developers more flexibility when creating new applications or customizing their devices according to specific preferences.

2. Customization: The ability for users and manufacturers alike to customize their experience with themes or installing third-party launchers makes it easy for them to make the device their own or tailor it towards a particular audience.

3. Wide Range Of Devices And Price Points: Because numerous companies manufacture devices with differing specifications, screen sizes, processor speeds, etc., there are affordable options available at every price point - from high-end flagship phones down to budget-friendly handsets targeting those who want essential functionality without breaking the bank.

4. App Support: With millions of apps accessible via Google Play Store and alternative app marketplaces like Amazon Appstore or F-Droid (for free/open source software), consumers have ample choices when deciding what tools they need up close-by all times – be these popular social media offerings such as Facebook/Instagram/Twitter everything else under sun imaginable in-between!
